conclusion: Identify the quantity being described: accelerations of objects A and B.
Understand how acceleration is represented in a v-t graph: acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph at any given time.
Examine the v-t graph for object A. Observe the shape of the curve A from t=0 to t=t1. The curve is smooth and appears to be concave down throughout the interval.

Analyze the slope of curve A. The slope starts at a positive value, decreases as time increases, becomes zero at the peak velocity, and then becomes negative and its magnitude increases as time approaches t1. Therefore, the slope is continuously decreasing.

Relate the decreasing slope to the acceleration of object A. Since acceleration is the slope, the acceleration of object A is continuously decreasing from a positive value to zero and then to a negative value during the interval [0, t1].
Examine the v-t graph for object B. Observe the shape of the curve B from t=0 to t=t1. The curve is smooth and appears to be concave down throughout the interval.

Analyze the slope of curve B. Similar to curve A, the slope starts at a positive value, decreases as time increases, becomes zero at the peak velocity, and then becomes negative and its magnitude increases as time approaches t1. Therefore, the slope is continuously decreasing.

Relate the decreasing slope to the acceleration of object B. Since acceleration is the slope, the acceleration of object B is continuously decreasing from a positive value to zero and then to a negative value during the interval [0, t1].

Compare the observed behavior of the accelerations with the statement in the question, which says that the accelerations are first increasing and then decreasing. Our analysis shows that the accelerations of both objects are continuously decreasing.
Conclude whether the statement is true or false. Since continuous decrease is not the same as first increasing and then decreasing, the statement is false.
